title: Model
text:
Code
from palmerpenguins import penguins
from pandas import get_dummies
import numpy as np
from sklearn.linear_model import LinearRegression
from sklearn import preprocessing

title: Model
text:
Get Data


Code
df = penguins.load_penguins().dropna()

df.head(3)










species
island
bill_length_mm
bill_depth_mm
flipper_length_mm
body_mass_g
sex
year

title: Model
text:
Define Model and Fit


Code
X = get_dummies(df[['bill_length_mm', 'species', 'sex']], drop_first = True)
y = df['body_mass_g']

model = LinearRegression().fit(X, y)

title: Model
text:
Get some information


Code
print(f"R^2 {model.score(X,y)}")
print(f"Intercept {model.intercept_}")
print(f"Columns {X.columns}")
print(f"Coefficients {model.coef_}")


R^2 0.8555368759537614
Intercept 2169.2697209393996
Columns Index(['bill_length_mm', 'species_Chinstrap', 'species_Gentoo', 'sex_male'], dtype='object')
Coefficients [  32.53688677 -298.76553447 1094.86739145  547.36692408]

title: Model
text:
Turn into Vetiver Model


Code
from vetiver import VetiverModel
v = VetiverModel(model, model_name='penguin_model', prototype_data=X)

title: Model
text:
Save to Board


Code
from pins import board_folder
from vetiver import vetiver_pin_write

#model_board = board_folder("/data/model", allow_pickle_read = True)
#vetiver_pin_write(model_board, v)

title: Model
text:
Turn model into API


Code
from vetiver import VetiverAPI
app = VetiverAPI(v, check_prototype = True)

title: Model
text:
Creating Dockerfile


Code
#from vetiver import prepare_docker
#prepare_docker(model_board, "penguin_model")

title: Penguins Model
text:
Code
import duckdb
from palmerpenguins import penguins
from pandas import get_dummies
import numpy as np
from sklearn.linear_model import LinearRegression
from sklearn import preprocessing

title: Penguins Model
text:
Get Data


Code
con = duckdb.connect('my-db.duckdb')
df = con.execute("SELECT * FROM penguins").fetchdf().dropna()
con.close()

title: Penguins EDA
text:
Code
library(palmerpenguins)
library(dplyr)



Attaching package: 'dplyr'


The following objects are masked from 'package:stats':

    filter, lag


The following objects are masked from 'package:base':

    intersect, setdiff, setequal, union


Code
library(ggplot2)

df <- palmerpenguins::penguins




Code
df %>%
  group_by(species, sex) %>%
  summarise(
    across(
      where(is.numeric), 
      \(x) mean(x, na.rm = TRUE)
      )
    ) %>%
  knitr::kable()


`summarise()` has grouped output by 'species'. You can override using the
`.groups` argument.

title: Penguins EDA
section: Penguin Size vs Mass by Species
text:
Penguin Size vs Mass by Species


Code
df %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = bill_length_mm, y = body_mass_g, color = species)) +
  geom_point() + 
  geom_smooth(method = "lm")


`geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x'


Warning: Removed 2 rows containing non-finite outside the scale range
(`stat_smooth()`).


Warning: Removed 2 rows containing missing values or values outside the scale range
(`geom_point()`).

title: Penguins Tree Models
text:
Code
library(palmerpenguins)
library(dplyr)
library(ggplot2)
library(tidymodels)
library(randomForest)
library(rpart.plot)

tidymodels_prefer()

penguin_data <- palmerpenguins::penguins
df <- na.omit(penguin_data)







Code
set.seed(2025)

penguins_split <- initial_split(df,prop = 0.8, strata = species)

penguins_train <- training(penguins_split)
penguins_test <- testing(penguins_split)

title: Penguins Tree Models
text:
Code
library(palmerpenguins)
library(dplyr)
library(ggplot2)
library(tidymodels)
library(randomForest)
library(rpart.plot)

tidymodels_prefer()

penguin_data <- palmerpenguins::penguins
df <- na.omit(penguin_data)







Code
set.seed(2025)

penguins_split <- initial_split(df,prop = 0.8, strata = species)

penguins_train <- training(penguins_split)
penguins_test <- testing(penguins_split)

title: Penguins Tree Models
text:
Simple Classification Tree

Create Simple Tree and Fit


Code
class_tree_spec <- decision_tree() %>%      
  set_engine("rpart") %>%      
  set_mode("classification")

class_tree_fit <- class_tree_spec %>% 
  fit(species~., data = penguins_train)




Plot Fitted Tree


Code
class_tree_fit %>%
  extract_fit_engine() %>%
  rpart.plot()











Get Accuracy of Tree


Code
augment(class_tree_fit, new_data = penguins_test) %>%      
  accuracy(truth = species, estimate = .pred_class)


# A tibble: 1 × 3
  .metric  .estimator .estimate
  <chr>    <chr>          <dbl>
1 accuracy multiclass     0.941

title: Penguins Tree Models
text:
Bagging Approach

Create Bagging Model and Fit


Code
bagging_spec <- rand_forest(mtry = .cols()) %>%      
  set_engine("randomForest", importance = TRUE) %>%      
  set_mode("classification")

bagging_fit <- bagging_spec %>%    
  fit(species ~ ., data = penguins_train)


Note the default number of trees is 500


Show Important Predictors
Since Bagging uses an ensemble of trees (in this case 500), we are unable to plot them


Code
library(vip)
bagging_fit %>%       
  extract_fit_engine() %>%       
  vip()











Get Accuracy of Tree


Code
augment(bagging_fit, new_data = penguins_test) %>%      
  accuracy(truth = species, estimate = .pred_class)


# A tibble: 1 × 3
  .metric  .estimator .estimate
  <chr>    <chr>          <dbl>
1 accuracy multiclass         1


Seems as if the species in penguin data is easy to predict

title: Penguins EDA
text:
Code
library(dplyr)
library(ggplot2)
library(dbplyr)

con <- DBI::dbConnect(
  duckdb::duckdb(), 
  dbdir = "my-db.duckdb"
  )
df <- dplyr::tbl(con, "penguins")




Code
df %>%
  group_by(species, sex) %>%
  summarise(
    across(
        ends_with("mm") | ends_with("g"),
      \(x) mean(x, na.rm = TRUE)
      )
    ) %>%
  dplyr::collect() %>%
  knitr::kable()

title: Penguins EDA
section: Penguin Mass vs Bill Length by Species
text:
Penguin Mass vs Bill Length by Species


Code
df %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = bill_length_mm, y = body_mass_g, color = species)) +
  geom_point() + 
  geom_smooth(method = "lm")+
  labs(x = "Bill Length (mm)", y = "Body Mass (g)", title = "Penguin Size vs Bill Length by Species")

title: Penguins EDA
text:
Penguin Mass Spread by Species


Code
ggplot(df, aes(x = species, y = body_mass_g, fill = species)) + 
  geom_boxplot() +
  scale_fill_manual(values=c("Adelie"="red", "Chinstrap"="green", "Gentoo"="blue")) +
  labs(x = "Species", y = "Body Mass (g)", title = "Box Plot of Penguin Body Mass by Species")











Code
DBI::dbDisconnect(con)

title: Final Project
text:
C2C Ethan Stroup’s Final Project for Math 378

knitr::include_graphics("./penguin.jpg")








Penguins Model uses a Python script to perform linear regression on the Penguins data set, using bill length to predict body mass.
Penguins EDA uses an R script to present trends on penguin size vs mass based on penguin species.
Penguins Tree Models uses an R script to fit various classifications trees to the data set, predicting the species based on all other variable
